Popular AI chatbots like CHBT, Google Gemini, and Claude are applications built on top of large language models, LLMs, and they're fantastic at generating and editing text. Here's a simple visualization. You, the human, provides an input and the LLM produces an output based on its training data. For example, if I were to ask Chachi BT to draft an email requesting a coffee chat, my prompt is the input and the resulting email that's way more polite than I would ever be in real life is the output. So far so good, right? Simple stuff. But what if I asked Chachi BT when my next coffee chat is? Even without seeing the response, both you and I know Chachi PT is gonna fail because it doesn't know that information. It doesn't have access to my calendar. This highlights two key traits of large language models. First, despite being trained on vast amounts of data, they have limited knowledge of proprietary information like our personal information or internal company data. Second, LLMs are passive. They wait for our prompt and then respond. Right? Keep these two traits in mind moving forward. Moving to level two, AI workflows. Let's build on our example. What if I, a human, told the LM, "Every time I ask about a personal event, perform a search query and fetch data from my Google calendar before providing a response." With this logic implemented, the next time I ask, "When is my coffee chat with Elon Husky?" I'll get the correct answer because the LLM will now first go into my Google calendar to find that information. But here's where it gets tricky. What if my next follow-up question is, "What will the weather be like that day?" The LM will now fail at answering the query because the path we told the LM to follow is to always search my Google calendar, which does not have information about the weather. This is a fundamental trait of AI workflows. They can only follow predefined paths set by humans. And if you want to get technical, this path is also called the control logic. Pushing my example further, what if I added more steps into the workflow by allowing the LM to access the weather via an API and then just for fun use a text to audio model to speak the answer. Even if there were hundreds or thousands of steps, if a human is the decision maker, there is no AI agent involvement. key_facts: Large language models (LLMs) power popular AI chatbots like Chachi BT, Google Gemini, and Claude.
LLMs generate and edit text based on training data in response to user prompts.
LLMs lack access to proprietary information such as personal calendars or internal company data.
LLMs are passive and wait for user input before generating a response.
AI workflows follow predefined paths set by humans, including steps like searching calendars or accessing APIs.
Retrieval augmented generation (RAG) is a process that enables LLMs to look up external information before responding.
RAG is classified as a type of AI workflow, not an AI agent.
In AI workflows, the human remains the decision maker even when multiple automated steps are involved.
An AI agent replaces the human decision maker with an LLM that reasons and acts autonomously.
AI agents can reason about the best approach to achieve a goal and take actions using tools.
AI agents can iterate autonomously by evaluating their own output and refining it until criteria are met.
The REACT framework is a common configuration for AI agents involving reasoning and acting.
Andrew created a demo website showing an AI vision agent identifying skiers in video footage.
The AI vision agent reasons about what a skier looks like and then acts by analyzing video clips.
The average user benefits from AI agents that work without needing to understand backend complexity.
key_opinions: Most explanations of AI agents are either too technical or too basic for general audiences.
This video is designed for people with zero technical background but regular AI tool usage.
Terms like RAG and REACT are simpler than they appear once broken down.
The author finds the concept of agentic capabilities exciting and transformative.
The author believes AI agents will significantly impact how people interact with technology.
The author considers manual prompt iteration tedious and inefficient compared to autonomous AI agents.
The author views the REACT framework as the most practical setup for building AI agents.
The author believes users should focus on simple, functional AI tools rather than deep technical understanding.
The author suggests that mastering AI workflows is a stepping stone to building agents.
The author expresses enthusiasm about creating their own basic AI agent using Nan.
key_datapoints: The AI workflow runs automatically every day at 8 a.m.
The author uses Perplexity to summarize news articles in their workflow.
The author uses Claude to draft LinkedIn and Instagram posts.
The author compiles links to news articles in Google Sheets.
The author manually rewrites prompts when the output is not satisfactory.
The AI vision agent analyzes video footage to identify skiers.
The AI agent performs multiple cycles of self-critique to improve output quality.
The author mentions a free AI toolkit available via a link in the description.
The author plans to create a tutorial on a specific AI agent based on comment suggestions.
The video repeats the phrase 'AI. AI. AI.' six times at the beginning and end.
